newsitem.title: GERMANY: U.S. mulls complaint on German telecoms - report.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mulls complaint on German telecoms - report.

text.p: The U.S. government is considering filing a complaint against Germany with the World Trade Organisation to protest slow progress in deregulation in the telecommunications area, a newsmagazine reported.

In a summary of an article to be published in next week's edition, Der Spiegel wrote the U.S. is considering launching the complaint because Germany's post and telecommunications ministry has not acted quickly enough to open up the market.
In Washington, a spokeswoman for U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky could not confirm the report.
But she added: "The United States is very concerned about the introduction of competition and whether it meets the standards set in the WTO agreement" on telecommunication deregulation.
Officials at Germany's Post and Telecommunications Ministry were not immediately available for comment on the article.
U.S. and German officials met recently on the issue.
The magazine said the U.S. government has criticised Post and Telecommunications minister Wolfgang Boetsch for not forcing Deutsche Telekom to reach agreements with competitors.

Competitors like Arcor, eager to establish a foothold in the German market once it is fully liberalised on January 1, 1998, need to access Telekom's network in order to reach private clients, the magazine reported.
